metadata.title: Analyzing Health Insurance Market Data | by Sadrach Pierre, Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Healthcare.gov provides public access to the Qualified Health Plan (QHP) landscape data. The datasets include individual and family health plans available in states where the federal government is…

all_paragraphs: Healthcare.gov provides public access to the Qualified Health Plan (QHP) landscape data. The datasets include individual and family health plans available in states where the federal government is operating the marketplace. Quantitative analysis of available data on health insurance plans, as well as other healthcare services in general, may aid in making our healthcare system more transparent when it comes to pricing and value-based care.
In this post, we will perform exploratory data analysis on the QHP landscape data. The data is available here. It is also available as a ‘.csv’ file on my GitHub.
First, let’s store the data in a pandas data frame and print the list of columns:
We can also print the full list of columns:
As you can see there are 128 columns. We will limit our analysis to the following columns:

We can see that there are several categorical columns. Let’s define a function that takes as input a data frame, column name, and limit. When called it prints a dictionary of categorical values and how frequently they appear:
Let’s apply our function to the ‘Issuer Name’ column and limit our results to the five most common values:
We can see that the Issuer Name ‘Medica’ has the most records.
Let’s apply our function to the ‘County Name’ column:
As you can see, this is useful as a quick test to see if there is any significant imbalance in the data which is often a crucial thing to deal with when it comes to model building.

Next, it would be useful to generate summary statistics from the numerical columns like ‘Medical Maximum Out Of Pocket — Individual — Standard’. First, we need to convert the string-valued dollar amounts into float types.
And let’s make sure that the conversion worked:

Now, let’s define a function that takes a data frame, a categorical column, and a numerical column. The mean and standard deviation of the numerical column for each category is stored in a data frame and the data frame is sorted in descending order according to the mean. This is useful if you want to quickly see if certain categories have higher or lower mean and/or standard deviation values for a particular numerical column.
We can look at summary statistics of for ‘Issuer Name’ and ‘Medical Maximum Out Of Pocket — Individual’:
‘Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas’ has the highest Maximum Out of Pocket for Individuals and zero standard deviation accross plan types.

Next, we will use boxplots to visualize the distribution in numeric values based on the minimum, maximum, median, first quartile, and third quartile. If you are unfamiliar with them, take a look at the article Understanding Boxplots.
Similar to the summary statistics function, this function takes a data frame, categorical column, and numerical column and displays boxplots for the most common categories based on the limit:
Let’s generate boxplots for OOP_INDV in the 5 most commonly occurring Issuer Names:
We can perform similar analyses on the ‘Medical Deductible — Individual — Standard’. Let’s convert the string-valued dollar amounts into float types:
And let’s make sure that the conversion worked:
We can look at summary statistics of for ‘Issuer Name’ and ‘Medical Deductible — Individual — Standard’:
‘Wellmark Value Health Plan, Inc.’ and ‘Wellmark Health Plan of Iowa, Inc.’ have the highest mean ‘Medical Deductible — Individual — Standard’.
Let’s generate box plots for DEDUCT_INDV in the 5 most commonly occurring Issuer Names:
Finally, let’s define a function takes a data frame, categorical column, categorical value, and two numerical columns as input and displays a scatterplot:
Let’s generate a scatterplot of OOP_INDV vs DEDUCT_INDV for Medica:

I will stop here but please feel free to play around with the data and code yourself. I encourage you to perform similar analyses on the emergency room, specialist, and primary care columns. For example, it would be interesting to see how the percent coinsurance for primary care varies across issuer names.

To recap, I went over several methods for analyzing the health insurance market data. This included visualizing the data with boxplots and scatterplots. We also defined functions for generating summary statistics like the mean, standard deviation, and counts for categorical values. I hope this post was interesting. The code from this post is available on GitHub. Thank you for reading!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Writer for Built In & Towards Data Science. Cornell University Ph. D. in Chemical Physics.
